title: Initiative for strengthening community capacity in data processing and analytics in the digital age
text:
Table of Contents



Background and Rationale


Objectives


Research Questions


Theoretical Basis and Analytical Framework


Approach


Expected Outcomes


References









Background and Rationale


In the context of digital transformation, data is increasingly regarded as a strategic resource. The effective use of data plays a central role in policy design and implementation, social governance, and sustainable development. International organizations such as FAO, ESCAP, and the UN have repeatedly emphasized the importance of data capacity in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).


However, the current situation in many developing countries, including Vietnam, shows a significant lack of skills in data processing and analysis within the community. Many officials, students, and social organizations only have basic access (e.g., basic Excel), while lacking the ability to use more modern tools (Power BI, R, Python, Quarto). This limits the ability to make evidence-based decisions and apply data in local governance.







 <p><strong>Key international indicators:</strong></p>
 <ul>
   <li>
     <strong>Maƒçiulienƒó & Skar≈æauskienƒó (2019):</strong> civic tech communities 
     can only develop sustainably when they integrate three pillars: technology, knowledge, and people.
   </li>
   <li>
     <strong>FAO (2020):</strong> in a project in Papua New Guinea emphasized that the lack of baseline data 
     hindered the development of agricultural policy; continuous training, a standardized data framework, 
     and the application of simple technology (CAPI, GIS) brought about a breakthrough.
   </li>
   <li>
     <strong>ESCAP (2025):</strong> affirms that digital data governance 
     is a key factor in promoting the SDGs, and requires the active participation of the community.
   </li>
 </ul>




From these gaps, the implementation of the project ‚ÄúBuilding a foundation for community data processing and analysis capacity‚Äù is both an urgent and long-term requirement in the process of building a digital society in Vietnam.





 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/736x/f7/e0/56/f7e056e0c8181d44016dc971038774c4.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Objectives


2.1 General Objective








To develop and validate a community data capacity platform model to enhance the skills, knowledge, and data application capabilities of community groups, thereby contributing to promoting sustainable development and digital transformation.





2.2 Specific Objectives









Survey and assess the current state of community data capacity in Vietnam.


Design a multi-tiered training program (basic - advanced - applied) based on the following tools: Excel/Power Query/Power Pivot, Power BI, Stata, R/RMarkdown/RShiny, Quarto/Positron, basic Python.


Develop an open educational resource system (bilingual Vietnamese - English) with sample datasets that are practical and easy to access.


Establish Community Data Labs to create a space for practice, collaboration, and data-driven innovation.


Develop and validate a community data literacy maturity model (Community Data Literacy Maturity Model).











Research Questions









What is the current state of community data capacity in Vietnam and where are the main gaps?


Which data analysis tools are most suitable for the needs, level, and resources of the community?


Can the Community Data Labs model become a sustainable mechanism for enhancing and maintaining community data capacity?


How can we measure the progress of data capacity at both the individual and community levels?


Can this model be integrated with international programs (SDGs, FAO, ESCAP) to enhance its impact and scalability?










 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/1200x/15/72/ff/1572ff60f781820b9cdb5b333f003304.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Theoretical Basis and Analytical Framework



Theoretical Basis



Civic tech & digital data analytics framework (Maƒçiulienƒó & Skar≈æauskienƒó, 2019): three main networks ‚Äì Tech/Media, Knowledge, and Human ‚Äì are the basis for understanding how communities interact and develop data capacity.


Community capacity (Liberato et al., 2011): includes skills development, resource mobilization, network building, leadership, and participatory decision-making; can be adapted to measure data capacity.


Papua New Guinea experience (FAO, 2020): emphasizes the role of baseline data, simple but effective technology, and continuous training in enhancing national data capacity.


Digital data governance (ESCAP, 2025): requires data to be governed transparently, accountably, and sustainably, directly linked to the SDGs.





Research Analytical Framework



Inputs: tools, learning materials, training programs.


Process: operation within Community Data Labs, where data is collected, processed, analyzed, and shared.


Outputs: enhanced individual and community data capacity.









Approach








Mixed-Methods Approach


Combines quantitative surveys (measuring data capacity before and after intervention) and qualitative methods (interviews, group discussions) to both quantify the level of change and explain the mechanisms and context of the impact.











Implementation Activities


Implement the Community Data Labs model in a test-evaluate-adjust cycle, ensuring continuous improvement based on experimental feedback from learners and the community.









 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/736x/49/2c/be/492cbe801d7f8bd8609c2df85a3bb191.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Expected Outcomes









Enhanced individual capacity: at least 1,000 learners participate in the project and receive training, of which 200 achieve an advanced certificate.


Strengthened community capacity: a minimum of 10 community projects apply data to address priority social issues.


Sustainable institution: establishment of an independently operating Community Data Labs.


Open educational resource system: publication of bilingual materials (Vietnamese - English), sample datasets, and practical guides, that are easy to access and reuse.

title: Mission - Vision - Core Values
text:
Mission
    
      
        Connecting Vietnamese intelligence with global scientific trends
        Providing comprehensive solutions: data collection, management, analysis, and technology transfer
        Accompanying hospitals, research institutes, public and private healthcare units at home and abroad
        Promoting biomedical research, innovation, for a prosperous and humane future
      
    
  

  
  
    
    Vision
    
      
        To become a pioneer in Vietnam in scientific research and biomedical data
        To accompany the nation's era of growth, affirming the country's position on the world scientific map
        To contribute to improving the health and quality of life for the community
      
    
  

  
  
    
    Core Values
    
      
        Science: Transparency, standards, and objectivity in research and data analysis
        Innovation: Application of advanced technology, E-Health, and artificial intelligence in biomedicine
        Connection: A bridge of cooperation between hospitals, research institutes, businesses, and the international community
        Ethics: Strict adherence to ethical standards, confidentiality, and consent in research
        For the community: Creating specific reference data, improving the quality of treatment, and contributing to public health

About BIODAS  Institute of Biomedical Data and Science Research
text:
BIODAS ‚Äî Institute of Biomedical Data and Science Research
BIODAS is a research unit specializing in biomedical science and data science in Vietnam.
Our mission is to connect hospitals, research institutes, and public-private healthcare organizations domestically and internationally to promote medical research, develop technology, and improve treatment quality for the community.



  
  
    Training & Capacity Building
    
      Biomedical data collection & analysis: Excel, SPSS, R, data visualization.
      Clinical research methodology: study design, research workflow, scientific manuscript writing.
      Free seminars/webinars on biomedical research & data analysis.
      Direct mentoring from domestic and international experts.
    
  

  
  
    Scientific Research
    
      Collaboration with hospitals, research institutes, and universities in areas including: clinical research, public health, community surveys.
      Conducting research reports, scientific publications, and healthcare market research reports.
      Supporting field data collection & processing, assisting with patient recruitment according to research protocols.
    
  

  
  

  
  
    Development Direction
    
      Science ‚Ä¢ Connection ‚Ä¢ For the Community
      Expanding the academic-practice ecosystem: integrating training, research, and data.
      Strengthening collaboration with public-private organizations domestically and internationally.
      Enhancing research capacity in Vietnam, contributing to affirming the nation's position on the global scientific map.
    
  

  
  
    Market Research
    
      Healthcare and pharmaceutical companies: assessing market potential, identifying strengths, weaknesses, gaps, challenges, and investment opportunities.
      Hospitals and research institutes: developing service development plans and research collaborations aligned with community needs.
      Regulatory agencies: providing scientific evidence to support sustainable health policy and strategy development.

    Dr. Nguyen Cat Tuong is currently a Research Assistant at the Institute of Biomedical Research and Data Science (BIODAS). With a formal training background in Preventive Medicine at Hue University of Medicine and Pharmacy (graduated in 2025), Dr. Tuong is interested in the fields of public health, non-communicable disease management, and nutritional epidemiology.
    During his studies and research, Dr. Tuong has participated in many scientific works, typically research on the nutritional status of junior high school students in Hue (2023) and research on the availability and readiness of primary health care stations in the management of non-communicable diseases in Thua Thien Hue (2025). These publications reflect a research orientation associated with public health, practicality, and application.
    In his role as a research assistant at BIODAS, Dr. Nguyen Cat Tuong will accompany projects on biobank development, risk management, and biomedical data science, contributing to building a sustainable and internationally integrated research foundation.

Medical tourism market in Vietnam: An analysis of the current situation and development potential
text:
Medical tourism market in Vietnam:An analysis of the current situation and development potential

    
    
      1. Introduction
      
        In recent decades, medical tourism and wellness tourism have become prominent trends in the global tourism industry. According to the World Tourism Organization (UNWTO), this is one of six important development trends alongside ecotourism, community tourism, creative tourism, smart tourism, and responsible tourism. The global medical tourism market reached a scale of about 19 billion USD in 2018 and is forecast to increase to 30 billion USD by 2025 (Global Market Insights, 2019). Many Asian countries such as Thailand, Singapore, India, South Korea, and Malaysia have emerged as leading destinations thanks to a combination of supportive government policies, modern healthcare systems, developed tourism infrastructure, and well-built international brands (ITDR, 2020; Vietnam Briefing, 2023).
      
      
        Medical tourism brings dual value: not only does it contribute directly to economic growth through revenue from medical and tourism services, but it also helps to improve the capacity of the domestic healthcare system through the process of quality standardization, international integration, and investment attraction. In addition, the development of medical tourism is also associated with building a national image and brand, contributing to enhancing its position on the regional and global healthcare map.
      
      
        In Vietnam, medical tourism is in its early stages of development but has recorded positive signals. Each year, about 300,000 international visitors come to Vietnam for medical examination and treatment, bringing in an estimated revenue of 1‚Äì2 billion USD (VietnamPlus, 2025; Ministry of Health, 2025). However, this number is still modest compared to the potential. Meanwhile, the opposite trend of medical outbound is still very large, with about 60,000 Vietnamese people going abroad for treatment each year, spending about 2 billion USD (ITDR, 2020). A comparison of international medical costs shows Vietnam's clear competitive advantage: a spinal surgery costs only about 7,000 USD, much lower than in the US (110,000 USD), South Korea (23,000 USD), or India (12,000 USD) (Economics & Forecasting Review, 2025).
      
      
        In that context, research on medical tourism in Vietnam is of great significance, aiming to:
      
      
        Analyze the current market situation, including scale, trends, and strong medical specialties
        Assess the potential, advantages, opportunities, and challenges in developing medical tourism
        Propose strategic recommendations to develop this field in a professional, sustainable, and internationally integrated manner, contributing to making Vietnam a reputable healthcare destination in the region
      

      
      
        
          
        
        
          An Indonesian patient with rectal cancer was treated at the University of Medicine and Pharmacy Hospital in Ho Chi Minh City in July 2024. (Photo: VNA)
        
      

    

    
    
      2. Theoretical basis and analytical framework
      2.1. Concepts and classification
      
        Medical tourism is defined as the act of people traveling abroad to use medical examination and treatment services, surgery, dentistry, cosmetology, or advanced medical techniques at a reasonable cost and with guaranteed quality.
      
      
        Wellness tourism emphasizes resort services, spas, yoga, meditation, traditional therapies, and activities to improve physical and mental health.
      
      
        Some specific sub-branches have been identified, including reproductive tourism, cosmetic surgery tourism, dental tourism, or specialized treatment tourism (such as cardiology, oncology, organ transplantation).
      
      
        This classification allows for a clearer identification of the needs and motivations of international customers, and at the same time helps to build medical-tourism service packages suitable for each market segment.
      
      
      2.2. Determinants of development
      
        The success of the medical tourism industry depends on many factors:
      
      
        Healthcare system and service quality: including the professional qualifications of the medical team, access to advanced medical techniques, and obtaining international quality certificates (e.g., JCI). Vietnam currently has only 4 JCI-accredited hospitals, much lower than Thailand (67 hospitals).
        Treatment costs and international comparison: this is a core competitive advantage. Vietnam has much lower medical costs than developed countries (e.g., spinal surgery ~7,000 USD in Vietnam compared to 110,000 USD in the US).
        Tourism & transportation infrastructure: including the system of international airports, hotels, resorts, convenient transportation, as well as patient support services (interpreters, post-treatment care).
        Government policies and international cooperation: national strategies and resolutions (such as Resolution 59-NQ/TW 2025, Decision 147/QD-TTg 2020, Ministry of Health's 2023‚Äì2030 projects) emphasize making medical tourism a key economic sector. Bilateral and multilateral cooperation, along with the participation of the private sector, also plays an important role.
      

      2.3. Analytical framework
      To comprehensively assess the current situation and potential of the Vietnamese medical tourism market, the study can apply the following strategic analysis tools:
      
        SWOT (Strengths ‚Äì Weaknesses ‚Äì Opportunities ‚Äì Threats): to identify competitive advantages (cost, human resources, traditional medicine), weaknesses (lack of international brand, inconsistent infrastructure), opportunities (post-COVID-19 demand, global wellness trend), and challenges (regional competition, international standardization requirements).
        PESTEL (Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Environmental, Legal): to analyze the macroeconomic context affecting the industry, from national policies, economic trends, social-demographic changes, advances in medical-digital technology, to environmental factors and the legal framework.
        Porter‚Äôs Five Forces Model: to assess the pressure from competitors (Thailand, Singapore, India, South Korea), the threat of substitutes (Vietnamese outbound patients going abroad), the bargaining power of international customers, medical-tourism service providers, and barriers to entry for new businesses.
      
      The combination of these three analytical frameworks will create a solid foundation for assessing the current situation, potential, and strategic direction for the development of medical tourism in Vietnam in the period 2025‚Äì2035.

      
      
        
          
        
        
          Doctors at Saint Paul General Hospital in Hanoi perform surgery to treat a choledochal cyst for a 4-year-old Australian pediatric patient on December 5, 2023. (Photo: VNA)
        
      
    

    
    
      3. Research methodology
      3.1. Data sources
      This study is built on the basis of a combination of many types of data to ensure objectivity and comprehensiveness:
      
        Secondary data sources:
          
            Official statistical reports from the Ministry of Health, Vietnam National Administration of Tourism, General Statistics Office (GSO), World Tourism Organization (UNWTO), Global Wellness Institute.
            Industry and market reports from reputable research organizations such as IMARC Group, UnivDatos, Vietnam Briefing, ITDR, along with policy documents (Resolutions, Tourism Development Strategy, National Health Strategy).
            Scientific articles, specialized news, and case studies from mainstream press (VietnamPlus, Thiennhienmoitruong.vn, VNA).
          
        Primary data sources:
          
            Expert interviews: including hospital leaders, health sector managers, tourism businesses, economic-health experts.
            Customer surveys: opinions of international tourists, overseas Vietnamese, and Vietnamese people with experience of medical examination and treatment abroad or in Vietnam.
          
      

      3.2. Research methods
      
        Qualitative analysis:
          
            Content analysis of policy documents, national strategies, and industry reports to identify macroeconomic orientations.
            Application of strategic analysis frameworks (SWOT, PESTEL, Porter‚Äôs Five Forces) to clarify the context, competitive advantages, and challenges.
          
        Quantitative analysis:
          
            Use of statistical data (number of international visitors, medical expenditure, medical tourism revenue, number of IVF, dental, cosmetic treatments‚Ä¶).
            Comparison of medical service costs between Vietnam and competing countries (Thailand, Singapore, India, South Korea).
            o Market growth forecast based on data from IMARC Group (2025‚Äì2033) and UnivDatos (2025‚Äì2033).
          
      

      
      
        
          
        
        
          An English patient (center) with immune thrombocytopenia and a rare blood type was saved by blood donated by Vietnamese volunteers at Cho Ray Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City on March 25, 2024. (Photo: VNA)
        
      
    

    
    
      4. Current situation of medical tourism in Vietnam
      4.1. Scale and trends
      
        International visitors to Vietnam for treatment: According to the Ministry of Health, each year Vietnam receives about 300,000 foreign visitors for medical examination and treatment, mainly concentrated in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi (VietnamPlus 2025). Revenue is estimated at 1‚Äì2 billion USD/year (Vietnam Briefing 2023).
        Vietnamese going abroad for treatment (outbound): About 60,000 Vietnamese go abroad for medical treatment annually, spending 2‚Äì3 billion USD (ITDR 2020). This shows a large "foreign currency drain" due to trust in the international healthcare system.
        Market growth: In 2024, the size of the Vietnamese medical tourism market reached 722.3 million USD, expected to increase to 3.7 billion USD by 2033 with a CAGR of 17.8% (2025‚Äì2033) (IMARC 2025).
        Customer trends: Foreigners coming to Vietnam are mainly from the ASEAN region, Australia, South Korea, Japan, and overseas Vietnamese. They are interested in dental, cosmetic, IVF, minimally invasive surgery, and traditional medicine services.
      

      
      
        
          
        
        
          A Cambodian patient with Whitmore's disease recovers after three weeks of intensive treatment at City International Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City in June 2025. (Photo: VNA)
        
      

      4.2. Prominent medical specialties
      
        Dentistry & aesthetics: Ho Chi Minh City is a leading dental service center, with costs much cheaper than Australia and the US (only 1/3 ‚Äì 1/4) (ITDR 2020). Aesthetics and dermatology are also developing, with the Ho Chi Minh City Dermatology Hospital trusted by many international clients (VietnamPlus 2025).
        Obstetrics & gynecology & infertility: Vietnam performs about 30,000 IVF cases annually, leading ASEAN (ITDR 2020). Complex surgeries such as fetal cardiac intervention (Tu Du Hospital & Children's Hospital 1, 2, 2025) have gained international recognition.
        Cardiology, oncology, complex surgery: Viet Duc, Bach Mai, Cho Ray, 108 hospitals have received many failed cases from Europe, Japan, Australia and treated them successfully (VietnamPlus 2025).
        Traditional medicine, rehabilitation, wellness: Vietnam has an advantage in rich medicinal resources, acupuncture, and physiotherapy. The Ho Chi Minh City Institute of Traditional Medicine has implemented a model combining treatment and resort, but its effectiveness is still limited due to the lack of all-inclusive service packages (VietnamPlus 2025).
      

      
      
        
          
        
        
          Vietnam possesses a rich source of medicinal materials and traditional medicine, creating great potential for the development of medical tourism. Illustration: International delegates experience the method of examination and treatment with Vietnamese traditional medicine at an event organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 2019. (Photo: VNA)
        
      

      4.3. International comparison
      
        
          Treatment costs:
          
            Spinal surgery: US ~110,000 USD; South Korea ~23,000 USD; India ~12,000 USD; Vietnam ~7,000 USD (Economics & Forecasting Review 2025).
            Heart surgery: Vietnam 10,000‚Äì15,000 USD, much lower than Thailand (25,000‚Äì30,000 USD) (Vietnam Briefing 2023).
          
        
        
          International certification: Vietnam has only 4 JCI-accredited hospitals (Vinmec, FV, Hoan My, Hong Ngoc), much lower than Thailand (67 hospitals). This is a major barrier in terms of brand and reliability.
        
        
          Competitive destinations: Thailand, Singapore, and India have advantages in global marketing, strong support policies, and specialized services. However, Vietnam has the advantage of low costs and skilled medical human resources.
        
      

      4.4. National policies and strategies
      
        
          Resolution 59-NQ/TW (2025): identifies medical tourism as a potential field for development in international integration.
        
        
          Resolution 153/NQ-CP (2025): implements a project to develop internationally standardized specialized medical centers.
        
        
          Vietnam Tourism Development Strategy to 2030: prioritizes health tourism, spas, mineral springs, and traditional medicine services.
        
        
          Ministry of Health's 2025‚Äì2030 project: aims to have at least 15 internationally accredited hospitals by 2030, including 5 public hospitals; build combined medical-tourism service packages.
        
        
          Inter-sectoral cooperation: The Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Culture, Sports & Tourism signed an MOU (2025) to promote cooperation, promotion, and the building of integrated medical-tourism products.
        
      

            
      
        
          
        
        
          The Vietnam Tourism Development Strategy to 2030 particularly emphasizes the development of high-quality, diverse, and unique tourism products, with priority given to tourism associated with healthcare. Illustration: Hot mineral spring bathing ‚Äì the top choice of Russian tourists when visiting Khanh Hoa. (Photo: VNA)
        
      
    

    
    
    5. Proposed SWOT analysis
    
      
      
        
          
        
        
          Source: Joint Commission International
        
      

    
    

      
        Strengths
        
          Competitive cost: Medical service prices are 50‚Äì80% lower than in developed countries (e.g., spinal surgery 7,000 USD in VN vs. 110,000 USD in the US) (Economics & Forecasting Review 2025).
          Quality human resources: Vietnamese doctors are highly skilled, with many internationally recognized specialized techniques (fetal cardiac intervention, limb transplantation, single-port endoscopic surgery) (VietnamPlus 2025).
          Diversity of services: Dentistry, aesthetics, IVF, cardiology, oncology, traditional medicine, and wellness.
          Rich culture & nature: Combining medical treatment with relaxation (beaches, UNESCO heritage sites, spas, mineral springs).
          Hospitality: Vietnamese people are friendly and hospitable, creating a positive experience for international patients (Vietnam Briefing 2023).
        
      

      
        Weaknesses
        
          Lack of international brand: Vietnam has only 4 JCI-accredited hospitals, much lower than Thailand (67) or Singapore (ITDR 2020).
          Uneven service quality: Large differences between public and private hospitals, central and local levels.
          Limited foreign language and marketing skills: Many facilities lack staff who can communicate in English/Korean/Chinese, and international communication is weak.
          Suboptimal tourism infrastructure: Limited connectivity of airports, hotels, and cross-border health insurance.
        
      

      
        Opportunities
        
          Global trend: UNWTO identifies medical tourism & wellness tourism as 2 of the 6 main development trends.
          Growing regional demand: 300,000 international visitors come to Vietnam for treatment each year (VietnamPlus 2025).
          Supportive policies: Resolution 59-NQ/TW (2025), 2025‚Äì2030 projects to develop specialized medical centers.
          Post-COVID-19 trend: Increased demand for wellness, spas, traditional therapies, and holistic healthcare.
          International investment: Vinmec, FV, Raffles, Gleneagles, Bumrungrad are expanding in Vietnam (IMARC 2025).
        
      

      
        Threats
        
          Strong regional competition: Thailand, Singapore, India, South Korea have global brands and international-standard infrastructure.
          Quality certification barriers: Requirement for hospitals to be JCI-accredited while VN has only 4 facilities.
          Foreign currency drain: 60,000 Vietnamese go abroad for treatment, spending 2‚Äì3 billion USD/year (ITDR 2020).
          Lack of a synchronous legal framework: Unclear regulations on international health insurance and cross-border payments.
          Risk of commercialization: If poorly managed, some facilities may abuse the medical tourism model, affecting the national reputation.
        
      
    

    
    6. Development potential
    
    

      
        Competitive advantage
        
          Low medical costs: Many services cost only 1/3‚Äì1/5 of those in developed countries (e.g., heart surgery in Vietnam 10,000‚Äì15,000 USD vs. Thailand 25,000‚Äì30,000 USD) (Vietnam Briefing 2023).
          Highly skilled medical staff: Many complex surgeries (fetal cardiac intervention, limb transplantation, single-port endoscopic surgery) have been successfully performed, demonstrating regional-level competence (VietnamPlus 2025).
          Diversity of services: Prominent in dentistry, aesthetics, IVF, cardiology, traditional medicine, rehabilitation, and wellness.
          Rich medicinal resources: Vietnam has a great advantage in traditional medicine and natural resources for therapy and healthcare (Thiennhienmoitruong.vn 2025).
        
      

      
        Market opportunities
        
          Post-COVID-19 trend: Increased demand for combining relaxation and holistic healthcare (IMARC 2025).
          Wide open regional market: Southeast Asia, Australia, Japan, South Korea have high demand for low-cost, good-quality services. About 300,000 international visitors come to Vietnam each year for medical treatment (VietnamPlus 2025).
          Rapid growth: The size of the Vietnamese medical tourism market is projected to reach 3.7 billion USD by 2033 with a CAGR of 17.8% (IMARC 2025).
        
      

      
        Policy drivers
        
          National strategy: Resolution 59-NQ/TW (2025) and Resolution 153/NQ-CP (2025) identify the development of medical tourism as a strategic direction.
          2030 goals: At least 15 hospitals to be internationally accredited (including 5 public ones), and specialized medical-tourism service packages to be built (Ministry of Health 2025).
          Inter-sectoral cooperation: The Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Culture, Sports & Tourism signed an MOU for sustainable medical tourism development for the period 2025‚Äì2030.
        
      

      
        Sustainable development orientation
        
          Combining healthcare ‚Äì tourism ‚Äì digital technology: Building a closed-loop service ecosystem (hospital ‚Äì hotel ‚Äì travel agency ‚Äì international insurance), while promoting digital transformation in medical registration, payment, and patient data management.
          National brand: Developing the ‚ÄúVietnam Medical & Wellness Tourism‚Äù brand with specific service packages such as dentistry, traditional medicine, and mineral spring resorts.
          International integration: Strengthening cooperation with global healthcare and insurance corporations, promoting Vietnam as a healthcare-wellness hub of ASEAN (UnivDatos 2025).
        
      
    

    
    7. Challenges and limitations
    
    

      
        Uneven service quality
        
          Although there are some internationally accredited hospitals (Vinmec, FV, City International‚Ä¶), the number of JCI-accredited hospitals in Vietnam is currently only 4 ‚Äì far too few compared to Thailand (67 hospitals) or Singapore (over 20) (ITDR 2020; Vietnam Briefing 2023).
          Many public hospitals are still limited in terms of facilities, management processes, and support services for international patients.
        
      

      
        Barriers in international branding and quality certification
        
          The ‚ÄúMedical Tourism Vietnam‚Äù brand has not yet established a position on the global medical map.
          There has been no large-scale international marketing campaign like Thailand's ‚ÄúAmazing Thailand Health & Wellness‚Äù or South Korea's ‚ÄúMedical Korea‚Äù (Vietnam Briefing 2023).
        
      

      
        Limitations in marketing and international cooperation
        
          Coordination between the health and tourism sectors is still fragmented, lacking a common strategy.
          Medical tourism products are still experimental, mainly stopping at pairing hospitals with travel companies without a closed-loop service chain (VietnamPlus 2025).
          Lack of an online promotion platform, multilingual information for international visitors (Thiennhienmoitruong.vn 2025).
        
              

      
        Tourism infrastructure, foreign languages, and cross-border health insurance
        
          The foreign language proficiency and international customer care skills of medical staff are still limited (ITDR 2020).
          There is no mechanism for linking international health insurance ‚Äì an important factor in attracting patients from developed countries (VietnamPlus 2025).
          Tourism infrastructure in some localities (transportation, hotels linked to hospitals) does not meet the standards for serving high-end medical tourists (UnivDatos 2025).
        
      

    

    
    8. Proposed conclusions and recommendations
    
    

      
        For the Government
        
          Develop a national strategy for medical tourism: Similar to Thailand and South Korea, a master strategy is needed to position Vietnam as a high-quality healthcare-wellness destination (ITDR 2020; Economics & Forecasting Review 2025).
          Complete the legal framework and incentive policies: Tax, credit, and land incentives for hospitals and businesses investing in the medical tourism sector; a separate medical visa mechanism for international visitors (Vietnam Briefing 2023; IMARC 2025).
          Promote international cooperation: Link with global health organizations (JCI, ISO) and expand regional cooperation in ASEAN to increase reliability and national brand (VietnamPlus 2025).
        
      

      
        For the Health sector
        
          Standardize service quality: Increase the number of JCI-accredited hospitals from the current 4 to at least 15 by 2030 (Thiennhienmoitruong.vn 2025).
          Enhance the capacity of medical human resources: Strengthen training in key specialties (dentistry, IVF, cosmetic surgery, cardiology, rehabilitation), while focusing on foreign languages and international patient care skills (Vietnam Briefing 2023).
          Apply digital technology: Promote telemedicine, electronic medical records, online appointment booking, and international insurance connection (IMARC 2025).
        
      

      
        For the Tourism sector
        
          Develop integrated product packages: Combine hospitals ‚Äì hotels ‚Äì resorts ‚Äì travel agencies, creating all-inclusive medical treatment + resort experiences (VietnamPlus 2025; UnivDatos 2025).
          Marketing & brand building: Promote international communication in multiple languages, promoting ‚ÄúVietnam Health Tourism‚Äù as a national brand (ITDR 2020).
          Invest in tourism infrastructure: Upgrade airports, transportation connecting hospitals with resorts, while developing support services for patients and their relatives (UnivDatos 2025).
        
      

      
        For businesses & hospitals
        
          Build an international brand: Strengthen cooperation with global healthcare and insurance corporations; proactively seek quality certification (JCI, ISO).
          Apply high-end technology & services: Implement AI, surgical robots, and modern biomedical technology to improve treatment quality (IMARC 2025).
          Promote digital marketing: Create an online information portal, a global appointment booking system, multilingual customer care, and engage with social media and international tourism platforms (Vietnam Briefing 2023).
        
      

    

    
    
      References

      
        1) 
          Nguyen Thi Hien (2025). International experience and lessons for developing medical tourism in Vietnam in the new context. Economics & Forecasting Review
        .
      

      
        2) 
          Thiennhienmoitruong.vn (2025). Exploiting the potential for developing medical tourism
        .
      

      
        3) 
          VietnamPlus (2025). Vietnam an attractive destination for medical tourism
        .
      

      
        4) 
          ITDR (2020). Medical tourism: New chance in the near future for the Vietnam tourism industry
        .
      

      
        5) 
          Vietnam Briefing (2023). Medical Tourism in Vietnam: Opportunities and Challenges for Foreign Stakeholders
        .
      

      
        6) 
          UnivDatos (2025). Vietnam Tourism Market Size & Forecast (2025‚Äì2033)
        .
      

      
        7) 
          IMARC Group (2025). Vietnam Medical Tourism Market Report 2025‚Äì2033
        .
      

      
        8) 
          Duong Lieu & Xuan Mai (2025). Vietnam ‚Äì an attractive destination for medical tourism. Tuoi Tre
        .
      

      
        9) 
          Dinh Dai (2025). Medical tourism: Vietnam has great potential to attract international tourists. Business Forum
        .
      

      
        10) 
          Ha Thi Thanh Thuy (2025). Potential for developing medical tourism in Vietnam. Economics & Forecasting Review
        .
      

      
        11) 
          Le Thanh (2023). The attraction of South Korean medical tourism. Vietnamnet

title: Project on Developing a Practical Handbook for Data Processing and Analytics to Empower Communities in the Digital Age
text:
Table of Contents



1. Overview


2. Objectives


3. Scope and Audience


4. Proposed Structure


5. Development Methodology


6. Expected Outcomes


References








Overview


In the context of the 4.0 Industrial Revolution, data is considered the ‚Äúnew oil‚Äù of the knowledge economy. Effective data mining has become a core competency in healthcare, education, economics, public administration, and community development. However, many organizations and communities in Vietnam still face significant challenges.







 <p><strong>Key challenges:</strong></p>
 <ul>
   <li>Lack of systematic, practical guidance documents in Vietnamese.</li>
   <li>Uneven data analysis capacity, still dependent on manual tools (basic Excel, paper reports).</li>
   <li>Lack of connection between modern analysis tools (R, Python, Power BI, Stata) and practical applications in community management, public health, and sustainable development.</li>
 </ul>









 <p><strong>Recent international studies show:</strong></p>
 <ul>
   <li><em>Al Nuaimi & Awofeso (2024):</em> Data and Business Intelligence (BI) are drivers for improving the efficiency of the healthcare system.</li>
   <li><em>Dicuonzo et al. (2022):</em> BI plays a central role in the digital transformation of healthcare.</li>
   <li><em>Mansoor & Dar (2024):</em> The application of BI helps optimize the management of clinical testing processes.</li>
 </ul>




Therefore, it is necessary to develop an academic and practical handbook to guide data processing and analysis for the community, combining theory, tools, methods, and practical illustrations.





 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/1200x/7e/f3/25/7ef3258157f986edddcff4560d4f5d78.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Objectives


2.1. General Objective



To compile a practical handbook that is scientific, academic, but easy to access, to enhance the data processing and analysis capacity for communities, social organizations, and management agencies in Vietnam in the digital age.



2.2. Specific Objectives




Present a systematic theory of data, data quality, and data governance in the community.


Guide the use of popular tools: Excel / Power Query / Power Pivot, Power BI, Stata, R / RMarkdown / RShiny, basic Python, Quarto / Positron.


Introduce analysis methods: from descriptive statistics, inferential analysis to Big Data and Business Intelligence (BI).


Illustrate through practical case studies:


Application of BI in test management (Navify);


Big Data in the health supply chain;


Community dashboard using Power BI;


Public health data analysis using RShiny.


</li>
<li>Provide a training framework, sample datasets, exercises, and implementation guidance.</li>








 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/1200x/59/10/54/591054ce6be9e52eeaccbc0137c7f353.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Scope and Audience








Beneficiaries:



Healthcare workers


Statisticians ‚Äì managers


Civil society organizations


Students ‚Äì young researchers


Government officials












Scope of application:



Public health


Community governance


Education


Socio-economics


Environment












Limitations:


The handbook focuses on applied data practice, and does not replace statistics textbooks or advanced programming materials.









 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/1200x/62/9c/9a/629c9a49864362a9af59c5798fa75953.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Proposed Structure




Part I. Data Fundamentals and Data Governance



Concepts and classification of data (structured, unstructured, semi-structured).


Data lifecycle: collection ‚Äì cleaning ‚Äì storage ‚Äì analysis ‚Äì reporting ‚Äì application.


Data quality: attributes (accuracy, completeness, timeliness, integrity).


FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable).


Data security and community research ethics.






Part II. Data Processing Tools



Excel & Power Query/Power Pivot.


Power BI for reports and dashboards.


Stata: analysis of social and health quantitative data.


R & RMarkdown & RShiny: from basic analysis to web applications.


Python: pandas, matplotlib, scikit-learn for basic data analysis and automation.


Quarto/Positron: reproducible research, publishing scientific reports.






Part III. Data Analysis Methods



Descriptive statistics and visualization.


Linear and logistic regression.


Multivariate analysis: PCA, EFA, Cluster Analysis.


Latent Class Analysis (LCA) and Bayesian LCA.


Big Data Analytics and Business Intelligence: from theory to application.






Part IV. Data Visualization and Reporting



Scientific and aesthetic principles of data visualization.


Tool comparison: Excel, Power BI, ggplot2 (R), matplotlib (Python).


Dynamic reporting with RMarkdown, Quarto.


BI dashboards for health and social sectors.






Part V. Practical Applications



Health: disease forecasting, vaccine supply chain management.


Test management: data standardization, reducing processing time, and providing real-time dashboards.


Community governance: survey analysis, budget monitoring.


Education and society: analysis of training quality, labor market.






Part VI. Case Studies



Box 1: Business Intelligence in testing.


Box 2: Big Data in health supply chain management (COVID-19).


Box 3: Power BI dashboard for community surveys.


Box 4: RShiny for public health data.






Part VII. Data Infrastructure and Governance



Data storage systems (cloud, open data, big data warehouse).


Data integration from multiple sources.


International standards: HL7, FHIR (health), SDMX (social).






Part VIII. Training and Scaling



Design short-term training programs (3‚Äì5 days).


Develop an open resource repository: datasets, scripts, video tutorials.


Build a data practice community.








 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/1200x/96/aa/0e/96aa0e5b754142c0200eb61018d1d380.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Development Methodology



Implementation Process



Systematic literature review: referencing recent studies on Big Data, Business Intelligence (BI), and community data management (e.g., Dicuonzo, 2022; Al Nuaimi, 2024).


Expert interviews & workshops: working with statisticians, BI experts, public health officials to gather insights and practical requirements.


Pilot implementation: applying the materials at hospitals, universities, and community organizations to evaluate effectiveness and applicability.


Editing & standardization: combining academic foundations with practical illustrations; standardizing terminology, processes, and lesson structures.


Feedback loop: gathering feedback from pilot users, improving content and accompanying tools.










Open Access Publishing:



Release interactive PDF and website.


Publicly release project source code (scripts, templates) on GitHub.


Develop an online course (MOOC) with sample datasets and exercises.










 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/1200x/52/22/58/522258963ffe7af9f360463802a1d357.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)






Expected Outcomes



Deliverables



An academic‚Äìpractical handbook (‚âà 200‚Äì250 pages).


A set of illustrative case studies with dashboards, source code, and sample data.


An open online resource repository (documents, scripts, templates).





Training Implementation



Organize at least 03 pilot training courses.


Reach a minimum of 200 trainees (from various fields).





Expected impact: Contribute to enhancing digital capacity for communities and social organizations, promoting data-driven decision-making practices.







 <img src="https://i.pinimg.com/1200x/2e/d4/e2/2ed4e2245a4e4caad104b0d79c6331a5.jpg" class="img" />


Illustration (Source: Internet)

References

Dicuonzo, G., Galeone, G., Shini, M., & Massari, A. (2022). Towards the use of big data in healthcare: A literature review. Journal of Healthcare Engineering, PMC9322051.  https://doi.org/10.1155/2022/9322051
